creator: dvp@inbox.ru

comments.text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/61.0.3163.100 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce:

Connect to remote machine by windows remote desktop client.
Start Firefox in remote session. 
Detach from the session and reattach again to it.


Actual results:

Firefox drops javascript variables screen.width and screen.height to 0.




Expected results:

Firefox set javascript variables screen.width and screen.height to proper values accourding virtual desktop resolution.

Bug appears since version 55 and and has remained in 56
comments.author: dvp@inbox.ru

comments.text: Jim, do you know why we'd be doing this over an RDP connect/reconnect cycle? Not sure about component or priority here, either.
comments.author: overholt@mozilla.com

comments.text:
Jonathan, you touched nsScreen.cpp in bug 1246346; any thoughts as to what could be going wrong here? (I'm really just looking for someone who has some idea, so sorry if this is an odd request)

There's also the possibility Milan's work in bug 1387514 (which I reviewed!) affected things here, but that seems doubtful.
comments.author: overholt@mozilla.com

comments.text: Any chance of a mozregression run?  Although with RDP, that would take a while.
comments.author: milaninbugzilla@gmail.com

comments.text:
reporter, have you ever used mozregression? It would help track down when this started occurring.

http://mozilla.github.io/mozregression/quickstart.html
comments.author: overholt@mozilla.com

comments.text:
(In reply to Andrew Overholt [:overholt] from comment #2)
> Jonathan, you touched nsScreen.cpp in bug 1246346; any thoughts as to what
> could be going wrong here?

Not really, sorry. I don't think bug 1246346 looks particularly relevant here.

At a guess, I wonder if disconnecting/reconnecting an RDP session invalidates our Screen objects, but perhaps doesn't trigger whatever notification would cause us to properly refresh things. So then the window can no longer find the (new) screen it's on, and returns something empty.

If this regressed in Firefox 55, I suspect the substantial reworking of screen code that happened in bug 1194751 might be involved; forwarding needinfo? to :kanru.
comments.author: jfkthame@gmail.com

comments.text:
I get mozregression and bisection proccess stopped at:
Bug 1354998 - stylo: Update test expectations for contain property r=emilio
MozReview-Commit-ID: 4B570Lb5Auu
comments.author: dvp@inbox.ru

comments.text:
(In reply to dvp from comment #6)
> I get mozregression and bisection proccess stopped at:
> Bug 1354998 - stylo: Update test expectations for contain property r=emilio
> MozReview-Commit-ID: 4B570Lb5Auu

Thank you for going through mozregression! Unfortunately that seems like it couldn't be the cause here as it's just changing some tests.

Let's wait to see if Kan-Ru has any thoughts.
comments.author: overholt@mozilla.com

comments.text:
Just tried to reproduce this but was unable too. STR:

1) connect to a desktop via Microsoft RDP
2) open nightly
3) open develop console
4) note the values within the screen object
5) disconnect RDP / reconnect over RDP
6) check the screen values again

results: screen values of width and height are correct
comments.author: jmathies@mozilla.com

comments.text:
I tried to reproduce but was unable too. STR:

1) connect to a desktop via Microsoft RDP
2) open nightly
3) open develop console
4) note the values within the screen object
5) disconnect RDP / reconnect over RDP
6) check the screen values again
7) disconnect RDP
8) change RDP screen resolution setting and repeat step 1-6

Reporter, would you mind enable the logging and reproduce it again to get more info?

Steps to enable logging:

> Open cmd.exe
> cd c:\
> set MOZ_LOG=timestamp,WidgetScreen:5 
> set MOZ_LOG_FILE=%TEMP%\log.txt 
> cd "Program Files\Mozilla Firefox"
> .\firefox.exe

Once you've reproduced the problem, exit Firefox and look for the generated log files in your temporary directory. You can type "%TEMP%" directly into the Windows Explorer location bar to get there quickly.

Following is the log I get which shows the screen dimension change was detected correctly

comments.author: dvp@inbox.ru

comments.text:
This certainly happens, is often enough to be very annoying, and does not appear to be directly related to abandoning an RD session and then reconnecting. I just managed to reproduce yet another time by simply updating Firefox from 58 something to 59.0.1 over an RD session to a Windows 7 machine without abandoning the session during the process - when it relaunched itself after the update it was invisible.

In my experience it only happens when launching the first instance of Firefox (without any Firefox processes already running), and I would say it happens much more often on Windows 7.

Once you get out of the problem and manage to see a properly sized Firefox window, it's not going to happen again for some time.

I don't think I've seen it happening even once on Windows 10, then again, I usually log out of the RD sessions to my Windows 10 PC and usually keep the RD session to the Windows 7 PC running. So it would appear that the problem has a much bigger chance to happen if Firefox is launched from under a long running RD session, regardless of when it was abandoned.

From the user point of view, it is very unclear how to get out of this situation when it happens, because Firefox appears on the taskbar as running but there is no visible window (it's located at [0,0] and has zero size). You have to shift-click the Firefox taskbar button to show the old-style window menu, then select Move and then move the window out of [0,0] with the keyboard, which will also resize it to its minimum possible size, then you can resize it more with the mouse.
comments.author: gserg.g@gmail.com

comments.text:
Just happened to me on the fresh Windows 10 April update to which I was connected via remote desktop, and the RD session was brand new as well (i.e. not long running).

I clicked to update Firefox to version 60, it restarted, and the Welcome page that opens after that was zero sized and in the top left corner.
comments.author: gserg.g@gmail.com

assigned_to_detail.name: nobody@mozilla.org
assigned_to_detail.real_name: Nobody; OK to take it and work on it

summary: zero screen size on terminal session
